column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: granny, 75 or over Female  (Patient)
column9: First time I was not able to wake up after outpatient procedure and was transferred to mail hospital until I finally woke up more than 12 hours after injection.More than 5 years later I was given the same drug and do not remember talking to doctor or leaving the hospital or anything else for more than 24 hours after injection. Thankful to my husband for taking care of me and trying to keep me awake.I am making sure that I have a card with all my reactions listed, with me at all times. There was no record at the hospital and I did not remember the name of the drug.

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: cstmsbkr, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I get colonoscopies every 3 years due to family history & had been given this drug before along with Demerol, had no problems, & it worked as it was supposed to do. Was given these 2 drugs again for the most recent colonscopsy,but something went horribly wrong. Going into the recovery room, I flatlined & they had a hard time getting me back. I was not aware of my surroundings & have no memory of that day or the following 3 days. Apparently I was able to function & communicate but remember NOTHING! Went back to the hospital a week later to find out what went wrong & all they would say is that I had a bad reaction to the drugs & they had to administer drugs that were supposed to counteract the effects but they didn't work (these additional drugs are what they give people on a drug overdose). I believe that I was given an overdose which would suppress breathing, etc. & wanted to sue but couldn't get a lawyer that wanted to take the case. Since then, I've had problems with memory & have seen a neurologist who did an EEG & he says that I have small seizures which results in temporary memory losses. I will never have these drugs again or use that hospital. Beware!! Talk with the doctor & make sure that they are using a dose appropriate with your weight, etc.

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: karen, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been reading some of the reviews, and it seems that people have (on average)  either a very good experience or very bad... I know that every person reacts to a drug differently, and also that the experience and skill of administering doctor seems to be very important.Having said that, my experience was excellent.  I had it for a bone marrow biopsy.  The doctor had done many, many of these procedures (he was a hemotoligist).  My experience that time, was that I was so relaxed and euphoric, that I would gladly have any procedure with this drug (and this doctor).  I was able to communicate, and semi-aware of what was happening, but had no pain, no anxiety. Frankly, for me, with this doctor and dose, what so good, that it is good that it is not available except in controlled environments.  I commented after the procedure that the doctor could have told that he was going to cut off my head, and I would be happy about it. I did not have any bad reaction, no nausea, etc, and woke up feeling great. I remember getting somewhat philosophical and commenting on my ability to think clearly  after the procedure and when recovering and standing up.Of course I can't speak for other people, but for me, this sis THE drug of choice for procedures of this type. I don't know if I also had fentenyl (sp?) with it as others have noted.

column2: Didi, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was given this drug when I went in for injections in my lower back.  I was told it would put me temporarily asleep, but I was awake the whole time, but feeling absolutely no pain from the injections.  I've broken out in a rash with itching, but not sure if the Versed is the reason or one of the other medications given; i.e., fentenyl or marcaine.  Hopefully it'll go away soon.  Had no problems afterwards, stopped and got something to eat afterwards, went home and relaxed rest of day and went back to work next day.   Except for the rash and itching...everything is fine.

Just had the second for RNC(killing the nerve in spine for the facets. and I felt the first shot of Versed(little dizzy) then I felt the whole procedure. I talked the whole time of the procedure. Would not want this used again.

column1: Induce Temporary Amnesia
column2: melme, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was given versed through IV for injections in my spine.  I was placed face down on table and versed line was attached.  I was given a dose of versed.  I complained of hand pain.  Then complained that my iv site was leaking.  It was checked and I was told it wasn't.  I complained again that my hand hurt.  I heard a nurse say release her pressure cuff.  I remember little about my experience after that!  I am on day 2 now still wondering what the heck happened other than, my guess:  Given several does of versed before them noticing my pressure cuff was blocking the medication in my hand.  Just posting this so no one else has the iv and cuff on the same arm!  My aunt who was there said they kept me for a very long time becuase every time I fell asleep my blood ox level went down to 90 and I would quit breathing.  I'm so glad my aunt was with me who had prior medical training as a nurse for over 30 years.  She got me home safe and my daughter sat with me the whole day into the night!  What I don't understand is how this happened?  I'm sure they do hundreds of these if not thousands a week....why did they not figure it out prior to giving me the versed.

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: Gwen, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had a CT guided biopsy of the left adrenal gland in May 2011 at the Mayo Clinic in Jacksonville.  It was excruciatingly painful.  First, the area on my left back near the spine was deadened with Lidocaine, then I was literally STABBED five times.  First when a tube was inserted then four additional times through the tube with a needle with grips or something on the ends to collect specimens.  As I begged and pleaded for something for the pain I was assured that I had been given three hits of Versed in my IV.  Finally, screaming and crying, I was just going to get off the table ( lying on my stomach) and was forcibly held down.  Furious when they finally let me up, I went back to the recovery room and immediately dressed myself but they would not let me leave for one hour.  Too bad.  I was leaving but I had to sign a paper.  NEVER!!! again with this drug.  I have an appointment again very soon at the Mayo and fully expect a lung biopsy be suggested.  I will take two or three milligrams of Xanax before I go and tell them so when I meet my oncologist, radiologist and endocrinologist consultations before hand.  I would very much like to be on the clinical trial with the drug that will shrink the thyroid cancer tumors in my lungs, adrenal glands and liver but not at the expense of all that horrible pain.  This drug was worthless and I would have fared better with Ibuprofen.  Then they had the audacity to offer me a turkey sandwich, I hate turkey.  My husband ate it.  Now I know to take my own sandwich in my purse along with a Diet Coke.

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Versed is an odd drug. I've been administered it many times for many liver biopsies and a cholangiogram. If you're being administered this for a surgery, make sure your doctor has given you an post-surgery nausea medication (mine recommended Ondanestron for a liver biopsy, but I'm no pharmacist). Either way, make sure you get the nausea medication before they give you this and the surgery, otherwise don't eat afterwords. It'll give you a cold feeling as the drug travels through your system, and then the effects will hit. Pain won't register, pressures will, and yes, you will have a hard time remembering what happened. However as far as an anesthesia medication that doesn't completely knock you out, it works well, it's also easy succumb to the sedative effects post surgery and get some good rest after the surgery!

column9: I use this drug for a stint change every 4 months.I get severe nausea and a headache.I also have anxiety feelings that I have yet to shake off after 2 months.I will not use this drug again.Also I have what seems like memory loss.I feel like I am in a fog some days.

column1: Calming of Intubated Patient by Administration of Sedative
column2: , 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This drug should be banned from use. It left me with a 10-15 year permanant memory loss and Post Trumatic Stress Disorder. I recieved this drug for an endoscopy back in 1991 and it was ineffective so they kept giveing me more and more until I stopped breathing. When I was revived, I became combative and had a paradoxical reaction to this drug. I woke up covered in bruises and was unable to turn my head. I wouldn't wish what happened to me to happen to anyone.I wouldn't even let my Vet use this drug on my dog when I took him to be fixed. The FDA needs to take this off the market, it's dangerous, cruel and causes permanent brain damage.My friend had a colonoscopy with Versed after I warned her repeatedly to refuse the drug. She was paralyzed, in severe pain (she has IBS) and was crying, but was unable to screamn out that she was in pain. She said it was like midevil torture. I warn everyone about to undergo any operation, dental work or procedure that may require sedation to state that they are allergic to this drug and refuse it.What is the purpose of an "Amnesiac?"  None as far as I'm concerned. I mean you KNOW you're going to have surgery or a dental procedure or test done, what is the purpose of causing amnesia other than to make the Dr.'s job easier by making the patient a compliant zombie. If they're in pain, who cares? They won't remember a thing.....well I have news for the medical profession...some of us DO remember what you did to us and are suffering permanant damage from what you did to us!!!

column9: supposedly given 12 mg versed with 75 mg demoral post colonscopy.  (got this information from report to Internist) Awake and in extreme pain during procedure.  Watched both camera and bp monitor when not screaming or kicking or grabbing side of bed.  nurse told me to take deep breaths.  Extreme pain.  Discharge instructions stated procedure "well tolerated"!  Do believe I was given 50 mg of demoral as nurse told me she was giving it to me.  I had told her I had high tolerance to pain medication and sedatives.  Called clinic records administrator and she related that papers signed by physician noted 50 mg demoral only.  Shge said unusual not to give versed too. Pre-op instructions indicated that I would be given a IV sedation.  Will NEVER use this physician again.

column1: Induce Temporary Amnesia
column2: Jim, 65-74 Male  (Patient)
column9: I have been administered this drug many times by IV prior to surgery.  The last time was on June 4,2009.  I was having rotator Cuff surgery and they were going to do a nerve block prior to surgery.  They told me I would be in twilight sleep during this proceedure or at least I would not remember it.  The drug was injected and the proceedure was started.  They have to hunt for the nurve and sometimes it takes some time.  The doctor told them to give me some more Versed.  In about another 30 seconds he told them to give me all of it. He finally found the nerve and injected it.  I was never sedated and of course I remember the complete proceedure.  As I usually do I crawled from the gurney onto the operating table myself.  I'm sure this must be a good drug for many but it does not work well for me. I have had the same experience with many of these drugs including pain killers. I am going to make sure my Doctor knows that drugs don't work well for me prior to my next scheduled surgery at MD Anderson on 10/21.

I didn't know about the amnesia effect.  Just as well. I may have worried about it unnecessarily, because it never happened.  Anyone I have spoken to who has had Versed say the same thing.  They love it.

column1: Additional Agent to Induce General Anesthesia
column2: prayerful, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: This drug was given to my 77 yr old mother for a knee replacement....that wasn't all that got replaced.  for 7-10 days after she was combative, had halucinations, and experienced a lasting case of 'Sundowners Syndrome'.  The precautions on this drug PLAINLY state that older patients need to be monitored very carefully on the dosage given - I firmly believe that this drug added to the beginning effects of Alzheimers.  That became her prognosis  only 3yrs later.Now my husband has had back surgery and developed an infection - they gave him Versed Inj on Wed. today is Saturday and he is still experiencing the amnesia, head aches, muscles aches and GRUMPYNESS.  I want my HUSBAND BACK!  I Declined this drug in 2001 for my surgery - certainly GLAD I did!!!! I WOULD NOT recommend this drug for any one unless you have done your homework on it!  I should have declined it for my husband - with diabetes and back surgeries we certainly didn't need what it seems to keep giving.  Disoriented, amnesia, violent chills, headache, and it should be noted that when its used as an additional agent to induce anesthesia for a surgical procedure - if you take pain meds (especially percocette) it compounds the effects of the Versed.  So if you need pain med - the versed will keep on giving!  I only hope that it will clear out of his system.  I DON'T RECOMMEND ANYONE USE IT as it induces Alzheimer like reaction, agitation, ....DATE RAPE???  someone might not know they'd been raped but with the lasting side effects they'd know that something unpleasant happened.

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This was given to me before an Upper GI type of test.  It was given through an IV in small doses at a time until I was out.  I was out the entire time the test was being done and had no discomfort at all.  I would recommend this medication as it worked very well for me but understand it doesn't work as well on some.

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: This drug was administered to my 23 month old toddler so that an infected nail could be removed from her hand while she was awake. Though my husband and I pushed for another route we were assured that there were no side effects to the drug and that our daughter was at low risk. WRONG!!!! She had severe reactions to the drug including but not limited to abnormal heart rhythm, delirium, anxiety (that lasted for at least a week following the administering of the drug),easily angered or annoyed (also for about a week following), and over excitement. This was an aweful experience to go through with a small child. Talk frankly with your Dr and look up the drug before you let them use it!!!!

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column9: The drug worked exactly like it was supposed to work.  My dissastifaction comes from not being told by my doctor about the amnesia effect. I found that extremely disturbing, and I've suffered anxiety and depression since being given this drug two months ago for a routine colonoscopy.

column1: Additional Agent to Induce General Anesthesia
column2: 25-34 Male  (Patient)
column9: Had a urethral cystoscopy and they injected me with 2 mg while in pre-op.  It worked very fast and was very effective.  I was out of it, did not care about upcoming surgical procedure anymore.  No post surgical side effects besides minor drowsiness.  Highly recommended.

column1: Additional Local Anesthesia
column9: This medication made me sick for 5 days after it was injected through my IV. I had nauseous, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, and could not stomach nothing for 5 days. Will not take this medication again. First time I had it I also had the same effect, as the second time..

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was given this drug for a colonoscopy and endooscopy on May 12th 2008. Im still having the feeling of dizziness and foggy mind 2 days after the surgery. Anyone else have this? Email me at angeliz8385@yahoo.com

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: Haywood Jablomi, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Worked decent for me before/during a SI Joint Denervation procedure.  Helped calm me down some I guess since it was my very 1st time being sedated in my life.  If this was supposed to help pain...it failed in that regard because I could feel every move that the Dr made and every move hurt but was tolerable and short lived.  For anxiousness I would say this works.  For pain none at all that I could tell because I have had similar procedure without any sedation or pain relief this actually hurt worse!  Atleast it takes some anxiety away of getting naked in front of a bunch of people.  Humm....maybe it's pretty good stuff afterall!

column1: Other
column2: SPARKY, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I HAD LOW BACK INJECTIONS  HAD A RACING HEART. TOLD DR .BUT HE SAID IT WSA OK THAT DAY OF MY NEXT INJECTION HAD #2 INJ. HEART RACED FASTER 170-190.NOW HAVE TACHACARIDA. SORRY I TOOK THIS DRUG I NEED HELP HAS ANYONEELSE HAD THIS HAPPEN TOO THEM?I AM NOW AFFARID TO TAKE ANY  MEDS .

column1: Additional Agent to Induce General Anesthesia
column2: deedlebop37@aol.com, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: colonoscopy/EGD worked great, didnt know when I was going to be given it. The nurse came from behind and put it in my IV as I was having my throat numbed by another nurse, after throat was numbed nurse behind me said "ok lay on your left side" dont even remember my head hitting the pillow. no pain, no discomfort at all but very "out of it" for the rest of the day and night. would highly recommend.

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: brokenangel2003, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This medication was used to relax me before I had 2 steroid injection in different areas in the spinal area. I did not feel a thing except a very slight pinch when the numbing medication was injected. Also have had this medication before two surgeries for pre-surgery anxiety. Worked well then too.

column1: Induce Temporary Amnesia
column2: cakelady, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Used w/demerol for colonoscopy and used alone for endoscopy. Both times were fine, had no problems whatsoever.

column1: Induce Temporary Amnesia
column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was given this, without consent, during my colonoscopy. This was the ONLY drug they used. No pain killers or anything. If people say that this drug worked for them it is only because they were given that in addition to pain medications through an IV. This drug only has a calming effect as well as an amnesic effect, it is not a pain killer. If you are only given this drug you will be in massive pain. Believe me I was. This drug is given to erase the memory of a traumatic medical procedure. Do this not sound unethical to anyone else?

column1: Additional Local Anesthesia
column2: Snowden, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have steroid injections in my spinal cord every three months. This medicine has made me able to go through with this painful procedure.Great results,I was tired most of the day but felt fine altogether.

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: 19-24 Female  (Patient)
column9: was given before endoscopy. i love this drug, i wish i could take it before every plane ride!!

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: Not impressed, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Endoscopy / Colonoscopy - I remember enough to know it was not a pleasant experience.  This drug does not work for everyone and if it doesn't, the experience can be horrendous.

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Used before doing an MRI, helped a great deal.

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: campy59, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Used for a colonoscopyVery effective,no pain or discomfort.After effects were gone after a few hours.Wish i could take this drug for my next plane ride !

column1: Other
column2: arachnib, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I too was given this for my colonoscopy on Dec. 6, '07. It worked well, but for 48 hours I was lightheaded, restless, cold and clammy, nauseous, muscle aches and pains. 4 days after the procedure, I'm still foggy and out of it.

column1: Induce Temporary Amnesia
column2: serialmom12, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: this drug is TERRIBLE. it caused nausea, vomiting and loss of equilibrium for three days after it was administered. it is also known as the 'date rape' drug. Stay away from this stuff.....far away if you're smart!!!!!!

column1: Sedation with Ability to Respond to Stimulation or Speech
column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: The medical personal gave it to me before I had a colonoscopy. I remember none of it. I was out like a light after the injection. No after-effects.
